data.title: Becoming an American Writer: The Life and Works of Isaac Bashevis Singer
data.meta_description: Becoming an American Writer is a grant program for libraries interested in organizing programs on the life and stories of Isaac Bashevis Singer (1904-1991) for the public.
data.text:
The centennial celebration

Becoming an American Writer: The Life and Works of Isaac Bashevis Singer will organize, present, and support public programs on the life and work of the Nobel Prize-winning writer Isaac Bashevis Singer (1904-1991). The most famous Yiddish writer of the twentieth century, Singer was an immigrant writer who made himself an American writer, in the process transforming American culture and being transformed himself, in his life and in his work.

Coordinated by

The Library of America in cooperation with the ALA Public Programs Office and with support from the

National Endowment for the Humanities,

Becoming an American Writer provided $450 grants and the three-volume authoritative collection

Isaac Bashevis Singer: Collected Stories (The Library of America, July 2004) to 60 libraries of all types across the country interested in organizing Singer programs for the public.
